titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I attended this morning at Judge Davis’s house, and completed the taking of Mr: Head’s deposition— But we could not get it finished for this day’s mail— I wrote to Mr: Pendleton, and also to Mr: Ingersoll, respecting the cause of Messrs: Boardman and Pope against the Hope Insurance Company at Providence— My brother and his wife were this day in town— This afternoon I went out with my wife, and son John, in the Stage to my father’s house at Quincy.

2. Heard Mr: Whitney, morning and afternoon— At the beginning of the Evening I went with my wife to Mr: Cranch’s, where our eldest son George is boarding, while he goes to Mr: Whitney to school— We made only a short stay there, and pass’d the remainder of the Evening at my father’s—

3. Mr: Cranch came down to my father’s this morning with George— Returned to Boston with my wife and children— It was the day for the annual election of Governor and Senator’s, but I did not attend the meeting— I spent the afternoon and Evening at home, excepting a walk with Catherine Johnson and the children in the Mall— Resumed the reading of French, with George; and also the teaching of Dufief’s grammar— Began reading Delille’s translation of the AEneid

4. Forenoon at my Office— After dinner at home reading writing and teaching George— Walking in the Mall early this Evening we met my friend J. Gardner— Attended a meeting of the Market Directors at Mr: T. Williams’s, and after a great variety of proposals we finally agreed upon the form of the deeds, and on a proposition to be submitted to the Company, a meeting of whom to be called for next Monday Evening— The Directors adjourned also to the same Evening.

5. Storm and rain confined me the whole day to the house— In the Evening however I called and pass’d an hour at Mr: Foster’s; my next door neighbour— I employed the day in writing, and teaching George— Read the remainder of the first Book of Delille’s AEneid—

6. Annual Fast day— Heard Mr: Buckminster in the morning, and Mr: Emerson after dinner— Remainder of the day confined at home; the weather continuing foul and stormy— Teaching George his french lessons, and writing— In the Evening I read the second Book of Delille’s AEneid— I perceive again the disadvantage, which I have heretofore laboured under at home— The distraction of multiplied occupations— So many trifling things to do, filch away by half-hours all my time; and leave me none for a steady pursuit of any one valuable object.

div.p: 7. Doctor Waterhouse called upon me this morning, and I went with him to Cambridge— Dined with him— Attended the Declamation at 2. And immediately afterwards read my Lecture 11.— I then pass’d about an hour at Dr: Waterhouse’s, in reading over some papers relative to a charge against him concerning his conduct as physician at the Marine Hospital in Charlestown— His son John came with me into Town— I was an hour at the Athenaeum, and the remainder of the Evening at home— Read Delille’s 3d: AEneid.

8. Morning at my Office; attending at the Supreme Court of the State now in Session— And at the Insurance Office— Afternoon and Evening at home— Dr: Welsh was here a couple of hours— In the Evening I read Delille’s 4th: AEneid— I am much pleased with this work. Dr: Waterhouse called on me twice this morning.

9. My wife, and the two boys, and Catherine, with me, heard Mr: Emerson, morning and afternoon— Dr: Waterhouse called this morning; and Mr: Lovell on his account, just before dinner— I advised the Doctor, on the course he is to take in the enquiry to-morrow— He supposed Mr: Blake the District Attorney was to attend and prosecute charges against him— And wished me to attend with him as his Counsel— I thought it would be best for him that there should be no interference of lawyers in the case; but engaged to attend in his behalf, if Mr: Blake should appear against him— I received while Mr: Lovell was with me a line from him, saying that I need not attend; as no lawyer would be there.— I read two Sermons of Massillon—Petit Careme—this Collection was preached before Louis 15. during his minority—in his chapel—those which I this day read are 1. On the character’s of Christ’s greatness— And on the falseness of human glory— From the last Sterne took much of his famous Sermon upon Conscience— They are all excellent Sermons— In the Evening I read some of Delille’s remarks on the third and fourth books of the AEneid— I continue to instruct George in the French language.

10— I was occupied part of this forenoon in writing, and the remainder of it, at my Office— Afternoon gave a lesson to George— At 6. in the Evening there was a meeting of the Market-Association and afterwards of the Directors— The Company approved what the Directors had agreed upon— But a new difficulty afterwards arose, and we adjourned to meet at my house Thursday Evening at 7.

11. I called with Dr: Welsh this morning at Dr: Warren’s, and they together with Dr: Warren junr: examined my left eye with a view to ascertain the seat of the complaint in it— They think they succeeded, and believe it is not absolutely a fistula, but an obstruction of the passage through the upper eye-lid into the sac— I called at Mrs: Newton’s— My brother was in town and dined with us— There was an attempt to send up a balloon from the gun-house on the Common in our neighbourhood this afternoon, but it failed— In the Evening Mr: William Foster junr: and his wife, a French Lady, with their eldest daughter were here—

12. Mr: William Foster junr: called on me with some papers relative to a contested title to land, which his father proposes to have tried at Law— Forenoon at my Office— Afternoon and Evening at home—with George; and reading part of Delille’s AEneid. Book 5.— It was our Club Evening, but I was prevented by the foul weather from attending.

13. I went to Mr: Foster’s Wharf and Stores, and examined the ground in controversy— My brother and his wife were in town and called, to see us on their return to Quincy this afternoon— This Evening the Directors of the Market Association met at my house, and pass’d several votes, with which we shall be enabled to make progress in the project.

div.p: 14. I went to Cambridge this Morning in the Stage— The badness of the roads prevented me from walking— Dr: Randall was with us in the Stage, and dined also at Dr: Waterhouse’s— I heard the declamation at 2. And read my 12th lecture at 3. We came to the Bridge in Dr: W’s Chaise, and walked thence into town— There was this Afternoon a solar Eclipse— Evening at home— Read the remainder of Delille’s AEneid 5. Catherine and George at Mr: Fosters.

15 Dr: Waterhouse had requested me to write something for him this morning, and called for it about 10. O’Clock— It was not ready, and I was obliged to go out upon other business— I promised he should have it on Monday.— We began this forenoon the execution of papers relative to the Boylston Market Association— I signed 65 Certificates, promising the delivery of the shares, on the payment of the three notes— Mr: Knapp the Treasurer and Clerk took them to collect the notes— I also gave my own three notes, which are to be taken up on the 17th: of May.— Louisa Smith came into town from Quincy, and in the Evening I went out there with my son John— I did not take George, as he is unwell.

16. I heard Mr: Whitney morning and afternoon— Remainder of the day chiefly engaged in writing for Dr: Waterhouse, and in looking into the Law-Books, relative to pleadings on the action of Trespass— Mr: Lisle of Milton was at my brother’s Office, this afternoon— Mr: Beale at my father’s part of the Evening.

17. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage— Susan Adams came in with me— Dr: Waterhouse called at my Office twice, and I gave him the paper he had requested— Mr: D. Everett called and I gave him a paper from Quincy— He is to call and see me at my house to-morrow afternoon at 4. O’Clock— Dr: Welsh called to make an appointment to meet me to-morrow morning at 9. O’Clock at Dr: Warren’s; for a further attempt to remove the obstruction in my eye— Mr: Dyer and Mr: Knapp were also at my Office, and we made progress in the business of the market— Most of the notes are collected— We got after no small difficulty Mr: B. Clarke’s Mortgage on the land discharged— Mr: Dyer gave me a new one, with his note payable on the 17th: of May. Mr: Clarke refused to assign his mortgage, or to do any thing but discharge it on payment of the money; which made it necessary to execute new instruments— In the Evening I went, with all the family to the Play; where we saw Hamlet, and the wrangling Lovers— Hamlet performed by Master Payne, a young Bostonian, who has the promise of great powers— And incomparably the first native American Actor I have seen— The house was excessively crowded, and the heat annoyed us very much— George and John, whom we took with us for the first time diverted us by their remarks and questions.

18. I went with Dr: Welsh this morning to Dr: Warren’s, where they made a new attempt to ascertain with a small probe, the spot where the obstruction to the passage of water from my eye exists— They were confirmed in the opinion previously formed. It is at the passage from the upper eye-lid into the lacrymal sac— They propose to open it with a lancet—but are to wait untill the vacation at Cambridge— I received the Deeds to the Boylston Market Association; executed by Mr: Dyer, and by Mr: Welles for Mr: Reed— Mr: D. Everett called on me this afternoon, and was with me about an hour— He wished for advice, and a promise of assistance for the conduct of his paper— We were invited to pass this Evening at Mr: B. Joy’s— But my wife being quite unwell we sent this Evening an Apology. Louisa Smith and Susan Adams spent the day abroad, but were here in the Evening.

19. I executed a deed for the Market Association, of the privilege of passage way to Messrs: Dyer and Reed; and they executed a partition, and other instruments between themselves— Mr: J. Welles acting for Mr: Reed.— Mr: W. Foster junr: called again upon me, respecting the law business which they are about to commence— Club this Evening at Dr: Kirkland’s— And it was well attended.

20. I was most of the forenoon at the Athenaeum, reading the English papers— Evening first at Mr: Ogilvie’s Oration on duelling and afterwards with a large party at Mr: Parkman’s— Mr: Ogilvie’s audience was crowded— He is a Scotchman— Speaks and writes handsomely, though with a strong accent in his pronunciation— I am again engaging in very thankless occupations, which I fear will take too much of my time.

div.p: 21. Morning at home— My brother called at my house just before I was starting for Cambridge— It made me late— I went directly into the chapel and attended the declamation— Called at Dr: Waterhouse’s for about 10 minutes & dined. Mrs: W. having prepared the table for me— They had dined— At 3. Read my Lecture 13— Walked to and from Cambridge. Evening chiefly at the Athenaeum reading the examinations on the charges in Parliament against the Duke of York.

22. A short time this forenoon at my Office— The Students at College, Bird and Bigelow called upon me this afternoon— They are to perform at the approaching exhibition— Sent George, first to dancing School, to Mr: Labottiere— He is to go only Thursday and Saturday in the afternoon— The half-Holidays at the other Schools— His other lessons I am afraid will suffer for it— But the graces! Oh! the graces! what is education without them?

23. Heard Mr Holley this morning, and Mr: Emerson in the afternoon— Read two Sermons of Massillon; of the lent Sermons preached before Louis 14. and pass’d the rest of the day in writing, and instructing George— Evening walk in the Mall, where I met George Mr: Quincy;

24. Boston Gazette contains my letter— I was at my Office a short time before dinner— Rest of the day at home; excepting a walk in the Mall— I have been writing some observations on the compilation just published as Works of Fisher Ames. The selection is a bad one, and I think it a duty to the public to prove it so.

25. Saw first in the Palladium of this morning President Madison’s Proclamation for the restoration of the commercial intercourse with Great Britain— I walked up to Cambridge, and attended the exhibition there, which was very good— The English orator was Bird— A fracas in the yard happened between young Sears and Winthrop— I dined with the Committee of the Corporation and Overseers at the Steward’s— Returning home I was overtaken by Mr: B. Pickman, who took me up— He asked me for a letter of Introduction to the President, which I promised to give him— I met Mr: B. Austin in the Street— He invited me to pass the Evening at his house, which I did; I found there a large party of ladies and Gentlemen, among whom were Mr: Gerry and General Dearborn; with Mr: Jonn: L. Austin— I had much conversation with Mr: Gerry— Mr: Ripley was at my house part of the Evening.

26. Called at the Patriot Office with papers and an Advertisement— I had about an hour’s conversation with Mr: Hall, at his Office— Dined at Mr: W. H. Boardman’s with a company of fifteen or sixteen Gentlemen— Evening with the club, at Mr: Quincy’s— We had much conversation upon the present political aspect of affairs— The first Sentiment upon my heart, at the great change which appears to be working is that of gratitude to Heaven.

27. Forenoon at my Office. Called at Mr: G. A. Cushing’s, and left his Papers— Dined with my wife and Catherine at Mr: G. Greene’s. Evening at home— Our children George and Charles are both unwell— The Company at Mr: Greene’s were about twenty—Ladies and Gentlemen— Among them, Mrs: Knox, and her daughter Mrs: Swan, with her husband— My sources of dissipation here are too numerous; and I must endeavour if possible to diminish them— I have not indeed had much lately to divert me from better occupations, of the same kind, as of this day and yesterday.

div.p: 28. I was employed at home, untill Noon— Then walk’d to Cambridge and dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— At 2. O’Clock I attended the Declamation, and at 3: read my 14th: lecture— Coll: Humphreys, and several other Gentlemen from Boston were there; with Mr: Ogilvie— Coll: Humphreys took me in his Chair with him, into town— I called upon Genl: Dearborn, at the request of Dr: Waterhouse, and had some conversation with him relating to the complaints against the Dr:—which have assumed a very serious and disagreeable complexion— I pass’d the Evening at home.

29. Dr: Waterhouse called upon me again this morning, and I had some conversation with him, and gave him some advice— I fear in vain— Mr: Ripley dined with us— In the afternoon I left my house to walk out to my father’s at Quincy; but at Dorchester, when about half-way out I was overtaken by Mr: Newcomb of Quincy, who was alone in a Chaise, and gave me a seat with him. I found my brother return’d from Dedham, and well— There was this Evening an eclipse of the Moon of 10 1/2 digits— I observed it before reaching my fathers house— It continued upwards of two hours.

30. Heard Mr: Guild of Milton, morning and afternoon— Went with my brother to my old dwelling-house; now inhabited by Mr: Faxon—to examine the number of the boxes of books which are to sent to me at Boston— In returning we stop’d for some time at Mr: Cranch’s— He shewed me an old letter, a copy taken from one of a Judge Sewall in the year 1721— It related to the family of that name; but contained the name of one of our Ancestors, a Mrs: Quincy, whose family and maiden name have been a subject of enquiry to Mr: Cranch these seven years. Evening in conversation with my father.

Day. Since my return from Washington I have hitherto been unable to resume even so much regularity of life, as I observed before my last journey there— The number of my occupations and avocations continues to multiply, and I fear will multiply still more— The modes of dissipation are becoming so numerous, that I must have Resolution to suppress some of them— I now usually rise between 6 and 7.— Read with George four chapters in the Bible—reading alternately with him, verse by verse—for the purpose of teaching him to read correctly, and of making him understand as well as I can explain it to him the contents— I shew him by the Abbe Grenet’s Map the Geography of the land of Canaan, and fix upon his memory the principal personages of the book, with the Genealogies— This takes us untill 8.— George then Breakfasts and goes to the town-School— I write in my chamber untill 9 and sometimes 10. Breakfast— Often engaged again in my chamber, or by somebody calling upon me, untill 11. or 12. Then a couple of hours at my Office—half an hour at the Insurance Office—(Fire and Marine.) Home to dinner— Afternoon and Evening at home— Hearing George read French; or Murray’s Grammar; after he returns from School at 5.— About dusk I usually walk about three quarters of an hour— And the latter part of the month I have spent many Evenings abroad. We seldom go to bed much before midnight.
